image.altText: Hayley Raso smiles and is hugged by her teammates

items.synopsis: The Matildas beat Denmark 2-0 to reach FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals. Earlier, England edges past Nigeria 4-2 on penalties in Brisbane.

title.children: 'We didn't get rattled': Matildas strike back after Danish assault to reach World Cup quarters

image.altText: Australian female soccer players jump high in celebration in front of a crowd of fans

items.synopsis: When will the Sam Kerr-captained side play again, and who will they be clashing with in the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup?

title.children: The Matildas have won their World Cup match against Denmark. What happens next?

image.altText: Bec Nicoll and Sarah Thomson crouch with their two dogs, on the ground of their wrecked house.

items.synopsis: Australians are facing a "broken" insurance system as the risk of bushfires, floods and cyclones increases with climate change, a new report out today says.

title.children: Bec and Sarah didn't want to repair a property that could just flood again. Turns out, their insurance claim wasn't that simple

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: Defence department's 'shocking' multi-billion-dollar reliance on consultants revealed

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Feels like hatred': Meet the town that voted 'no' in the last Indigenous referendum

image.altText: Steph Catley hands the Matildas' captain's armband to Sam Kerr during Australia's 2-0 win over Denmark in the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr returned to playing action and England survived a massive scare to beat Nigeria on penalties, despite having their young star sent off. Here are the five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits: Sam Kerr returns to triumphant Matildas as her club teammate sees red for England

image.altText: Hayley Raso (C) of Australia celebrates scoring the second goal for Australia

items.synopsis: The Matildas thrilled 75,000 fans in Sydney as they ran out 2-0 winners in their Round of 16 match, and the internet went wild.

title.children: How the internet reacted to the Matildas' 2-0 win over Denmark

image.altText: Toys, flowers and messages on heart-shaped papers line the Russell Island State School fence

items.synopsis: A Russell Island soccer club will observe a minute's silence to honour the memory of their 11-year-old goalie who died tragically in a house fire over the weekend.

title.children: 'It's just unbelievable': Shocked community grieves friends killed in devastating house fire

image.altText: A pile of Australian dollar coins on top of several bank notes

items.synopsis: Despite years of trade surpluses and a budget surplus to boot, the Australian dollar is on the slide once more — and it's all thanks to commodities and interest rates, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: How low can the Aussie dollar go? The answer lies in interest rates and commodity prices

image.altText: A slum from above

items.synopsis: Gautam Adani won the tender to transform one of the world's largest slums into a thriving, modern metropolis. But those in Dharavi fear the development could push them out and turn it into a playground for the rich.

title.children: India's rich and famous live on the edge of a Mumbai slum. Now the land has become highly coveted

image.altText: a woman running on the sand at a beach with a dog behind her

items.synopsis: The prolonged spell of warmer-than-normal weather in recent months is tipping 2023 as the firm favourite to set a new annual record.

title.children: New data reveals 2023 is on track for record heat — and next year should be even hotter

image.altText: Martin, Selena and Steve look at something beyond the camera with a shocked expression as they stand on a stage.

items.synopsis: With the most Oscar nominations in history, Meryl Streep hardly needs an introduction. But if you're yet to watch Only Murders in the Building, here's everything you need to know ahead of season three.

title.children: Meryl Streep has joined Only Murders in the Building. Here's your guide to the 'cosy crime' series

image.altText: A man and three women walk along a dirt track in outback Australia.

items.synopsis: A date for the Voice to Parliament referendum is yet to be announced because "there are still so many" Australians that need to be reached, Labor senator Malarndirri McCarthy tells Q+A during a special broadcast from Garma Festival.

title.children: 'The earlier the better, prime minister': Voice referendum date yet to be set amid promise of no delays

image.altText: A timber frame surrounds a multi-storey building under construction

items.synopsis: Tasmania's first multi-storey building using timber is taking shape on the city skyline, as pressure grows to use alternatives to greenhouse-gas-intensive materials like steel.

title.children: Timber once destined to become paper is now helping build high-rises

image.altText: Lee Hsien Loong speaks during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Does a string of scandals plaguing Singapore's government show that the system of oversight is working, or that such issues are inevitable without independent checks and balances?

title.children: 'Whiter than white': Why Singapore's recent spate of scandals have rocked the country

image.altText: Anutin Charnvirakul and Chonlanan Srikaew smile during a press conference announcing coalition party.

items.synopsis: Nearly three months after elections, Thailand's populist Pheu Thai party announces it will form a coalition government with the Bhumjaithai party and others.

title.children: Thailand breaks political deadlock with new coalition

image.altText: A desktop computer set-up with an office chair

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police reveals details of the joint FBI operation targeting child abuse material on the dark web.

title.children: Murder of two FBI agents leads to Australian sex abuse operation, removal of children

image.altText: a man is holding a bunch of spinach looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Dino Borrato lost close to $1 million and continues to plough some of his crop into the ground as the spinach industry recovers from last year's contamination event.

title.children: Spinach industry rebuilds reputation for producing 'very safe food' after contamination event

image.altText: Volodymyr Zelensky sits in a brown leather chair with a Ukrainian flag behind him

items.synopsis: Ukraine's intelligence agency detains a woman allegedly helping Russian authorities plan an air strike on an area Mr Zelenskyy visited last month.

title.children: Russian 'spy' arrested in Ukraine over role in alleged plot to blow up President Volodymyr Zelenskyy

image.altText: A composite image of a man with glasses in a suit and tie, and a woman with long hair.

items.synopsis: The head of an inquiry into judicial fairness as part of the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann is now the one under the spotlight.

title.children: 'Significant lapse of judgement': ACT government slams early release of report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Penny Wong, wearing a floral wreath in her hair, kneels next to Kiribati children holding Australian flags

items.synopsis: Australia will require both climate and gender objectives in much of its foreign aid spending, under a new framework aimed at strengthening Australia's influence in the Indo-Pacific.

title.children: China, climate and gender equality: Australia's new foreign aid policy aimed at building influence in Pacific

image.altText: nurses and midwives at a trike for better pay and conditions

items.synopsis: The vote by the NSW Nurses and Midwives' Association staves off industrial action, but the union says its members recognise 4 per cent isn't enough and vow to continue their fight for better pay.

title.children: NSW nurses accept government's 4pc pay rise in narrow vote 'driven by cost of living'

image.altText: An Asian woman and man smile for a photo as their picture is taken at a restaurant

items.synopsis: A Melbourne couple charged with enslaving a woman at their Melbourne home for 10 months has been ordered to stand trial, after several court delays and changes to their legal representation.

title.children: Melbourne couple to stand trial accused of modern-day slavery

image.altText: An illustration of a boy staring out a window from behind.

items.synopsis: Almost 33 per cent of Australians feel disconnected socially, and one in six feels severely lonely, according to a landmark study. But there are ways to feel less alone.

title.children: 'They feel really ashamed': Millions of Australians are lonely, but many find it hard to admit

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A court has heard that the woman accused of murdering her father by injecting him with her own insulin was last seen at his house hours before he was found unconscious.

title.children: 'Form of tranquilliser' found in the system of 94yo allegedly murdered by his daughter, court hears

image.altText: A man with fair hair and skin, wearing a suit jacket and an open-necked shirt.

items.synopsis: A rape case highlighting sexual assault and harassment issues in the mining industry ends with a former fly-in fly-out worker being sentenced to five years in jail.

title.children: Woman whose life was 'flipped upside down' by mine-site rape proud of speaking out, as attacker jailed

image.altText: Mushrooms stand on a patch of grass.

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives are still trying to get to the bottom of a suspected mushroom poisoning at a family meal in Victoria's east which led to the deaths of three people, who are being mourned as "pillars" of their community.

title.children: Daughter-in-law served poisonous mushroom meal that killed three, Victoria Police believe

image.altText: A woman in a large hat and sunglasses smiles broadly.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for billionaire Gina Rinehart seek to demolish a claim by a former business partner of her father Lang Hancock to a share of the jewel in her lucrative iron ore empire.

title.children: 'Fatal flaws' in argument underpin claim for slice of Gina Rinehart's iron ore empire, WA Supreme Court hears

image.altText: A woman in a white blouse stands in a park.

items.synopsis: Coroner Terry Ryan finds police officers "missed opportunities" to protect Samantha Schulte and remove firearms from her estranged husband before the siege.

title.children: Police response to fatal Christmas Day domestic violence siege 'inappropriate', coroner finds

image.altText: Three men, two old and one young, are wearing blue sports shirts with medals around their necks. They are happy.

items.synopsis: The famous sporting showdown on the Tiwi Islands drew local football fanatics and mainland tourists to Wurrumiyanga Oval on Sunday.

title.children: The triumph and defeat from the Tiwi Islands football grand final, in pictures
